title: Offshore multi-purpose platforms for a Blue Growth: A technological, environmental and socio-economic review
stakeholder_support:
Wave/wind: job creation, low carbon impact, etc
aquaculture: food production
conflicts:
ORE: visual obstruction and conflict with fishermen
WEC: fishermen and other ocean space users
Aquaculture: workers rights, environmental impacts

title: Food safety during seaweed cultivation at offshore wind farms: An exploratory study in the North Sea
Integrating Wind Turbines and Fish Farms: An Evaluation of Potential Risks to Marine and Coastal Bird Species
location: Coastal waters of western and northern Scotland
notes: Thought experiment to assess potential for increased collision risks to local marine and coastal bird species due to integration of small wind turbines; Used a sensitivity index with 12 factors and found that large gulls and European shag are at greatest potential risk;

title: Assessment of Multi-Use Offshore Platforms: Structure Classification and Design Challenges
Is Demonstrating the Concept of Multi-Use Too Soon for the North Sea? Barriers and Opportunities from a Stakeholder Perspective
policy_pathways: national variability. Key barriers include lack of MU-friendly policies
management_obstacles: requires MSP to process to enable co-existence of compatible actvities; discusses that some nations doNOT include Oil and gas as potential multiple use contributors
gross_cost_usd: NOT EXACT #. discusses availbility of economic incentives (only 1 nation had these) and other economic Drivers/barriers.
stakeholder_support: notes oppoition to aquaculture/OWF as a barrier
conflicts: notes oppoition to aquaculture as a barrier
notes: examined 10 MU combinations (3 involved aquaculture). Notes the lack of general MU definition. There is no way to uniformly do MU b/c each nation has different regulations and the NS is a highly contested and crowded space (user conflicts)

title: Development of multi-use platforms at sea: Barriers to realising Blue Growth
management_obstacles: 13 legal barriers were identified (6 hamper MUP development and 5 represent the lack of legislation to develop MUPs)
gross_cost_usd: NOT EXACT #. major economic barrier were identified (120 barriers across 6 categories)
stakeholder_support: notes that social dynamics are given less attention.
notes: FOCUSES ON BARRIERS TO MUP. qualitative review of 21 multi-use projects. focus on each project's contrbution to "Blue Growth".

title: Can multi-use of the sea be safe? A framework for risk assessment of multi-use at sea
management_obstacles: Risk. Calls for collaboration across organizations to manage correctly.
definition: Schupp et al. (2019; p4) define such multi-use as:‚Äù ‚Ä¶ the joint use of resources in close geographic proximity by either a single user or multiple users. It is an umbrella term that covers a multitude of use combinations in the marine realm and represents a radical change from the concept of exclusive resource rights to the inclusive sharing of resources and space by one or more users.‚Äù

title: Multi-use of the sea: A wide array of opportunities from site-specific cases across Europe
regulations: "the existence of a legal, regulatory and planning framework supporting and enabling MU is a key component for real MU development and operation."
gross_cost_usd: NOT EXACT #. but drivers and barriers noted
conflicts: most social barriers were linked to aquaculture

title: Assessing use-use interactions at sea: A theoretical framework for spatial decision support tools facilitating co-location in maritime spatial planning
stakeholder_support: "positive user" effects of shared visitor or shared staff
definition: ‚Äúthe same sea area can have simultaneously more than one use‚Äù
notes: Great and thorough definition of co-location and the other terms (section 2.1). Other conclusions are generally vague

title: Multi-uses in the Eastern Atlantic: Building bridges in maritime space
policy_pathways: Calls for MSP and maritime planning
regulations: "In other cases, despite national legislation and marine plans not addressing the MU concept, some sectoral strategic documents refer to the combination of activities or synergies amongst users. An example is the Irish Offshore Renewable Development Plan (Irish Government/ Department of Communications Energy and Natural Resources, 2014), which sets forward a list of project-level mitigation measures addressing interactions with other maritime users"

title: Sustainable use of marine resources through offshore wind and mussel farm co-location
location: Danish portion of Baltic Sea and western part of Danish North Sea
notes: Used multi-criteria evaluation (MCE) technique for co-locating offshore wind farms and open-water mussel cultivation to develop an index of co-location sustainability (SI)

title: Co-location opportunities for renewable energies and aquaculture facilities in the Canary Archipelago
location: Tenerife Island, Gran Canaria Island, Fuerteventura Island, and Lanzarote Island
phrase_identifier: Proposes a method that integrates several selection criteria, responding to the needs and limitations of marine aquaculture and renwable energy production in order to identify opportunities for the co-location of these activities; 3 steps: 1. evaluated suitability of studied area for exploitation of offshore wind/wave energy according to energy production and to structural, operational, and energy transport 2. evaluating suitability for farming 8 commercial fish species in offshore cages according to biological, structural, and operational aspects 3. integrate results for each activity and combined exploitation;

title: Socio-economic Analysis of a Selected Multi-use Offshore Site in the Baltic Sea
policy_pathways:
Discusses wind and aquaculture and env't separately:
Wind: section 3.2.3.1 "In general, the establishment of offshore wind turbines can follow two different procedures: a government tender procedure run by the Danish Energy Agency; or an open-door procedure."
Aquaculture: seciotn 3.2.3.2.
Environmental Concerns: section 3.2.3.3.
regulations: "The Danish Government provides the main conditions for offshore wind parks in the Promotion of Renewable Energy Act (Act no 1392 27th December 2008), and the Danish Electricity Act (Danish Energy Policy 2012)."
gross_cost_usd:
Wind: "The total price of the wind farm is expected to be between 2.0 and 2.7 billion Euro, whereof the grid connection is budgeted at 0.47 billion Euro." 
Salmon farming: "in existing 3000 tons farms, production costs are 2.85 Euro per kg and it is expected to have slightly lower production costs in a larger farm, but also slightly higher cost of insurance. Expected revenues from famring is 36 million Euro per year." section 3.4
Also discusses job creation.
stakeholder_support: Discusses "vulnerable" persons due to this project.
conflicts: Public perception. NGOs are opposed to auqauculture (more so than wind) due to emission of nutrients and the interaction with habitats and species. Later discusses need for EIA report. Also, lack of data to complete full social cost benefit analysis.
notes: MERMAID  project publication

title: Introduction to the MERMAID Project
gross_cost_usd: NOT EXACT # "Economic efficiency satisfies the condition that the marginal (social) cost of each production activity under consideration equals the respective marginal (social) benefit."
stakeholder_support: "Involving different stakeholders has shared and increased knowledge on the difficulties with regards to the development and implementation of MUŒüPs."
notes: MERMAID

title: Methodology for Integrated Socio-economic Assessment of Multi-use Offshore Platforms
notes: MERMAID

title: Socio-economic Analysis of a Selected Multi-use Offshore Site in the Mediterranean Sea
regulations:
Lists organizations of both aquaculture and offshore energy (Sections 6.2.3.1 and 6.2.3.2)
"It has to be stressed that aquaculture in the European Union (EU) is regulated by strict laws."
management_obstacles:
no regional or national legislation regulating renewable offshore energy in the region. No national or regional legislation exists to regulate subsidies for such
a project. Unlike other energy sectors, wind energy generation is at an early stage of
development and there is no established industry consensus on codes and
standards.
gross_cost_usd:
"The Northern Adriatic Sea site‚Äôs wind-fish farm requires 44 million euros for the establishment of the wind farm and it is expected to produce 1 million euros per year for 20 GWh per year in energy extraction. However, no more information is available. Hence, it was not possible to run the social cost benefit analysis for this function."
"Given the current market status (prices, days payable/receivable etc) the total fish farming investment is estimated at 18.8 million euros and is expected to break even at year 13"
stakeholder_support: Discusses "vulnerable" persons due to this project: coastal communities of Venice, energy industry suppliers, transportation industry, machinery industry, etc
conflicts:
Environmental impacts (table 6.3 and 6.4)
ALSO seems that this analysis yielded that this multi use solution was not viable: "Our preliminary, although tentative, analysis suggests that in the short term using a multi-use design with wind energy and fish production would be financially not sustainable, due to both low energy and fish production, and would bear high environmental risks. However, in the long-run, coastal and marine spaces might become more limited, and then going offshore will become more important to avoid unplanned and crowded uses in the future."
notes: MERMAID  project publication. Somewhat negative for co-location of fish farming. WOuld still need subsidies

title: Modelling study of the effects of suspended aquaculture installations on tidal stream generation in Cobscook Bay
Aquavoltaics: Synergies for dual use of water area for solar photovoltaic electricity generation and aquaculture
policy_pathways: "Processes are simplified and become easier when knowledge is free and easily accessible to both small time users and large companies"
management_obstacles: Rapid growth of the industry requires that policy is dynamic and safeguards the environment while protecting operation costs

title: Socio-economic Analysis of a Selected Multi-use Offshore Site in the North Sea
policy_pathways: Outlined in "Policy Document North Sea 2009 -2015". "However, this has not yet resulted in establishing a regulatory framework for multi-use."
regulations: Extensive regulations outlined for renewable energy generation in the Netherlands. Also there has been more prelimilary reference to Multi use of marine areas in national law
management_obstacles: "Already awarded permits for offshore wind farms such as the Gemini site are only for single-use. The absence of licences for multi-use production is a major obstacle. Also, as was mentioned above, there are no areas designated for offshore aquaculture in the Dutch spatial plans for the North Sea."
gross_cost_usd: Table 4.6 for both wind and mussel costs. Shows that it would be profitable. Wind farms would need subsidies
conflicts: lack of trust amongst potential users. Issues with fishermen who will lose fishing grounds. Environmental impacts
notes: MERMAID  project publication. Suggests that co locating bivalve cultivation with wind generation would be socio econoically and finacially viable

title: Risk Analysis for the Selected MERMAID Final Designs
notes: MERMAID

title: The feasibility of offshore aquaculture and its potential for multi-use in the North Sea
policy_pathways: "This requires the support of long-term investment potential, and long-term licensing and policies."
management_obstacles: "Despite the interest in combining functions in policy documents (MIE 2014), laws and regulations do not foresee in such combinations. Until recently, the concessions granted to offshore wind park operators made co-use illegal."
stakeholder_support: Best case scenario for stakeholder support would be to utilize co-management (concept of a covenant)
notes: Calls on the Dutch gov't to create these opportunites through subsities and MSP and co-management

title: The Governance of Multi-Use Platforms at Sea for Energy Production and Aquaculture: Challenges for Policy Makers in European Seas
policy_pathways: Makes 4 recommendations: 1) clear licensing procedure and framework, 2) financial support, 3) environmental management, 4) involved stakeholders from the onset
management_obstacles: Bureaucratic obstacles: authorizations, licenses, infrastructure, etc. Also, wave energy is still in its infancy and there is no regional or national legistlaion for it
notes: compares case studies from different North Sea regions. Most optimistic circumstances are with Southern North Sea

title: Participatory Design of Multi-Use Platforms at Sea
notes: Participatory design focused on MERMAID projects

title: A methodology for multi-criteria design of multi-use offshore platforms for marine renewable energy harvesting
regulations: "As for aquaculture, the Legislative Decree No.11954 of 2010, Art. 4 (1) on the Production of marine animals and algae by biological aquaculture"
management_obstacles: "The design of the MUP should follow the Regional, National and European legislation framework. However, the different uses have different level of regulations due also to the market development stage and number of existing installations."
notes: Presents methods for how to design co-located structures for specific areas

title: Boosting Blue Growth in a Mild Sea: Analysis of the Synergies Produced by a Multi-Purpose Offshore Installation in the Northern Adriatic, Italy
gross_cost_usd: NOT EXACT #. Cost increases with depth. The most cost effective choice of MUP from this project is the intregrated fixed wave energy devices, mini-wind and fish farm.
stakeholder_support: Stakeholder support will require a "participatory and multidisciplinary design process based on clear responsibilities and cooperation amongst users." also energy and tech sectors requested access to training MUPs
